channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Thereâ€™s No Such Thing as a Free Lunch . . . Or is There?
item.description: Hungry for a change? Itâ€™s only one click away! Our Houston-area client has several openings ranging from junior Perl programmers with 1-2 yearsâ€™ experience, all the way up to the 40-year veterans. Not in Houston? No problem! This company has a relocation program because they want to hire the best of the best.

item.title: Modern Perl developers needed to drive medical diagnosis into the future
item.description: A Cambridge-based provider of a revolutionary diagnostic tool for clinicians is looking for Modern Perl developers who are passionate about using their tech skills to help further the field of medicine. Youâ€™ll be building the tools that scientists are using to cure disease.

item.title: Do one thing, do it well, and do it with Perl (US)
item.description: The company has longevity as well, and thatâ€™s no accident â€“ they like what they do, and they do it well. Theyâ€™ve stuck with their core competency and forging considered and effective decisions across their history.

item.title: Sometimes, it's about the people - Perl developer in West London
item.description: Your average Perl development role, but with a personal recommendation from me that your colleagues are great people, and that Iâ€™d be surprised if you didnâ€™t enjoy your time there. Going to work each day is much more enjoyable when there's a great company culture and you actually like your colleagues..

item.title: Largest Perl team in London with beautiful Docklands offices
item.description: Large, dynamic Perl team in Canary Wharf looking for mid-level and senior developers. The company has maintained its small company feel, despite being bought a few years ago by a much larger company, and the office is super-friendly and supportive.

item.title: Barcelon Perl and Friends 2019
item.description: November 9, 2019 in Barcelona, Spain. A free one-day conference for Geeks and Friends

item.title: London Perl Workshop 2019
item.description: October 19, 2019. David Game College, 31 Jewry St, London EC3N 2ET

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: 2019.39 With A Lump
Perl Weekly Challenge 28
item.description: Roger discuss how he used Imager::Color to create Digital Clock. You must checkout his unique implementation.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 28: File Type and Digital Clock
item.description: Laurent shared nice little background of file type checking. I liked how he dealt in Perl6. You can't afford to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 028: File Content and Digital Clock
item.description: Choroba never used file test operator -T and -B operators before. In this blog, he shared his journey.

item.title: Fake Seven-Segment Displays with Perl and SVG
item.description: Dave impressed me with his Digital Clock solution. You must checkout.

item.title: Perl 6 Binary Clock
item.description: Arne discussed Task #1, Unicode vs ASCII in particular in great detail. You can't afford to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 028
item.description: Adam solved the "Digital Clock" using POE::Component::Schedule and some ANSI escape codes. Please do checkout.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Scimon Proctor
item.description: Please check out the short interview with the "Perl Weekly Challenge - 027" winner Scimon Proctor.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 028
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 029
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Grants: September 2019 Votes
Barcelona Perl & Friends - Talks
item.description: Checkout the talks lined up for the next Barcelona Perl & Friends 2019 event.

item.title: Flags, Switches and Unicode in Perl
item.description: Dave always pick the topic that is so commonly used in the devs life. He then starts analysing the different aspects that you would never bother talking about before. Dave's quality writing skill makes it very special.

item.title: Paws for Fun and Profit. Part the Second
item.description: Pease follow the PAWS blog series by John, part two.

item.title: Paws for Fun and Profit. Part the First.
item.description: John is back with the blog series on PAWS. Here is the first part.

item.title: A small DB change and a lot of problems
item.description: A short story about how a small DB change made Thomas question google cloud, Postgres and his sanity.

item.title: How to contribute to DEV this hacktoberfest
item.description: Ben shares ideas how to contribute to DEV.to.

item.title: Monthly Report - September
item.description: Usual monthly report about what I did last month.

item.title: LibreDWG - News: libredwg-0.9 released
item.description: Reini shared major release, the first beta, adding the new dxf importer, and dxf2dwg (experimental), the first usage of the new dynapi and the encoder.

item.title: Details of the new TPF blog site
item.description: Henry announced TPF news site has been moved to news.perlfoundation.org.

item.title: New TPF Blog Site Now Live
item.description: Jim announcing the new TPF blog site giving the details what went in.

item.title: #428 - Hackoberfest - Fun begins...
item.description:
Hi there

Digital Ocean sponsored annual event Hacktoberfest made an impactful start last week. Every social platforms were full of blogs about how to participate. brian d foy wrote an article to someone starting the challenge first time. Similarly, Gabor Szabo also wrote an article to guide first timers.

I also noticed "Perl Weekly Challenge" members actively taking part in the weekly challenge to fulfill the required number of Pull Request for Hacktoberfest. There are plenty of help available online, if you want to get on with the Hacktoberfest challenge. Feel free to contact me at mohammad.anwar@yahoo.com if you are running out of ideas.

Happy Hacking Hacktoberfest !!!
